summary: Build a portal website on ICP that hosts/links to an integrated suite of micro-apps/subsites (inspired by best-of-breed Web2/Web3 apps). Micro-apps should be easy to use with playful color-coded icons, support multilingual + multi-tenant orgs/users/vendors, integrate via shared APIs, include multi-wallet support, and provide owner/admin/user permissions with dashboards/metrics. Provide guidance on best-in-class pricing for offered services.
architectural_notes: Architecture is a portal hub + modular micro-apps/subsites connected via shared/internal APIs.
System should be multi-tenant (organizations), multi-user, and support multi-vendor.
Include multi-wallet capabilities for Web3 flows.
Access control model: Owner/Admin/User RBAC with privacy controls.
User approved proceeding with implementing the shared interoperability/backend API layer for identity, org context, roles, and activity logging across all micro-apps (AR-20).

existing_features.title: Create a portal-style home experience that serves as a hub for multiple micro-apps/subsites, including a searchable/browsable directory of micro-apps grouped by category (at minimum: AI, Banking, CashApp-like, DAOs, LinkedIn-like, Messaging, NNS, OpenChat-like, OpenClaw-like, Reddit-like, Social Media) and include additional best-of-breed categories beyond the initial list.

Implement a consistent, fun, playful, color-coded UI system for micro-app cards and navigation, using simple layouts suitable for broad age ranges. Ensure each micro-app category has a consistent color and icon style.
Add a coherent visual theme for the portal (colors, typography, layout) and apply it consistently across all screens. Avoid using a blue/purple primary palette.

Add routing and page shells for micro-apps so that each directory item opens a dedicated micro-app page (even if functionality is minimal initially). Include at least 6 starter micro-app shells inspired by the requested domains (e.g., simple social feed, basic messaging inbox UI, DAO proposals list, lightweight forum, basic vendor marketplace listing, basic AI prompt playground UI) without claiming to replicate external products.
Implement Internet Identity login and a shared identity layer in the app so all micro-app pages can access the authenticated user principal and display signed-in state.
Implement multi-organization (multi-tenant) support with the ability to create an organization, join an organization, and select an active organization context for all micro-app interactions.
Implement role-based access control with at least three roles: Owner, Admin, User. Provide basic privacy controls by enforcing role checks on sensitive endpoints and pages (e.g., dashboards/metrics).

Provide an Admin/Owner dashboard area with basic metrics and reporting across the portal and micro-app usage (e.g., counts of orgs, users, micro-app visits/opens, and recent activity). Ensure metrics are scoped by organization where appropriate.

Add multilingual infrastructure for all user-facing text (English as the default) and demonstrate at least one additional locale toggle with partial translations for core navigation and directory screens.

Add a vendors model to support “multi-vendor” scenarios: allow an organization to create and manage vendor profiles and associate them to relevant micro-app experiences (e.g., marketplace listing shell).
Add a “Pricing & Plans” page that provides guidance content for best-in-class pricing across micro-app categories, presented as editable content stored on the backend (so Admin/Owner can update).

Add generated static image assets (playful category icons + a simple portal hero graphic) and render them in the portal UI (directory cards, category headers, and landing hero). Store generated images under frontend/public/assets/generated and reference them directly from the frontend.
Fix role lookup in the frontend so that role checks use the caller principal (not the user profile object) and ensure role retrieval is consistent and reusable for all micro-apps.

Implement a frontend shared interoperability layer (a dedicated hook/module) that centralizes access to the interoperability context (profile, active organization, role) and provides a single, consistent way for micro-app pages to log activity with the correct org context.

Refactor existing micro-app shell pages that currently manually combine user profile fetching + activity logging so they use the shared interoperability layer for determining org context and logging app open events.

Add a compact test suite outline document for the shared interoperability layer that enumerates backend canister API tests for getInteropContext, getUserRole, and logActivity, including isolation tests, contract/shape assertions, multi-tenant boundary tests, workflow-chain tests, and failure-condition tests.

Include in the test suite outline a minimal, repeatable manual test execution plan using multiple identities (e.g., separate local identities for owner/admin/user) to exercise the interoperability APIs end-to-end, with concrete steps and expected outcomes.

new_feature_requests.summary: Create main ICP-hosted portal website that serves as a hub for integrated micro-apps/subsites

Provide micro-app directory/catalog UI with categories (AI, Banking, CashApp-like, DAOs, LinkedIn-like, Messaging, NNS, OpenChat, OpenClaw, Reddit-like, Social Media) and expand with additional best-of-breed categories
Clone available replica micro-apps from existing CaffeineAI system and modify to meet project specs
Implement shared API integration layer so micro-apps interoperate end-to-end
Add multi-language support across portal and micro-apps
Integrate multi-wallet support for Web3 functionality where applicable
Implement role-based permissions (Owner/Admin/User) with privacy controls
Create dashboards with metrics/reporting for authorized roles
Design playful, color-coded, simple UI with fun icons for broad engagement
Provide guidance/recommendations for best-in-class pricing for micro-app services
Implement a shared backend API layer that micro-app pages use for common capabilities (identity, org context, roles, and basic activity logging) to enable future interoperability between micro-apps.

Add a backend-level shared interoperability API that provides a single query to fetch the caller’s current interoperability context (authenticated principal presence, caller user profile, active organization context, and role for the active organization when available) so micro-apps can interoperate using consistent identity/org/role data.

Create a compact test suite outline for testing the shared interoperability layer (identity, org context, roles, activity logging) including isolation, contract, multi-tenant boundary, workflow-chain, and failure-condition tests
